Texas twists

It's been a tough few months for Josh Hamilton. The Texas Rangers outfielder has seen his batting average drop over 80 points since the end of May, heard heard boos from the once adoring Arlington crowd and been called out for giving up at bats by the president and CEO, Nolan Ryan. It hasn't helped that the Rangers were 9-14 in July after going 50-29 to start the season. Since the calendar flipped to August, first-placed Texas have gone 4-2, but trouble is still following Hamilton, who will be a free agent after the season.

Towards the end of July, Hamilton fed the Fort Worth Star Telegram comments that were described as "cryptic" by the local press.


"When the time is right, I'll be honest with you, you'll be right in the loop. I've been shown a lot of things over the past week. There's disobedience and there's obedience to God. I've been being disobedient. It may be a small thing to you, but it's a big thing to him. There's consequences. It's like a father and a kid. There are disciplines. You guys can chew on that and think about it."

This led to a frenzy of speculation surrounding the outfielder, who has struggled with alcohol and substance abuse and relapsed last winter at a Texas bar. Some believed the slugger, who despite the prolonged slump still has 29 home runs, just two behind the AL leader, Adam Dunn, was going through a divorce, or perhaps suffered another relapse. With the rumors running wild in Ranger land, Hamilton released a statement on Friday.

"I felt it was important to clarify what the issue was to which I was referring, both personally and professionally. The issue is discipline," his statement read. "Professionally, it's been plate discipline. Personally, it's been being obedient to the Lord in quitting chewing tobacco."

Hamilton continued: "I was hesitant to address the tobacco once again, because it's an area that I've struggled with trying to quit in the past. I wanted to have some time of success under my belt before addressing again publicly, but feel I haven't been given that option with all of the speculation out there as to what the mystery issue was. But there you have it – discipline."

Hamilton's struggle with the bat and his tobacco addiction isn't the only issue on the club, and while it may be premature to slap the Team Turmoil label on the Rangers, the sailing certainly hasn't been smooth lately in Arlington. Closer Joe Nathan revealed on Saturday that he has a dead arm, stating that the condition has nothing to do with his surgically-repaired right elbow. The 37-year old hasn't thrown since Thursday and has given up four runs in his last two outings, and seven runs over his previous seven innings.

Then there's the issue surrounding Roy Oswalt, who pitched out of the bullpen on Thursday and Sunday after going 3-2 with an ERA of over 6.00 since joining the team in late June. With Ryan Dempster joining from Chicago at the trade deadline and Scott Feldman pitching well, Oswalt was the reluctant odd man out of the rotation.

"Well, I mean we're 4-2 in the games I started. I guess I should've been 6-0. Two bad ones and won four of them so... I don't know. We'll see how it goes.

"It wasn't my decision," Oswalt continued. "I'm down there to throw when they need me, I guess... I don't know how long it's going to last."

Manager Ron Washington said it would be up to Oswalt how long he stayed in the pen, but that may have been lip service considering Feldman has won his last six decisions. On Sunday, Oswalt told his manager he couldn't go another inning after throwing two. Should the situation with the unhappy hurler escalate, the Rangers could put him on waivers and hope someone snatches up the veteran starter, who is still owed $4.5m this season.

After taking two of three in Kansas City this weekend, Texas will face challenging teams in Boston, Detroit and New York over the next 10 days.

Is this it?

The baseball world has been waiting for the Detroit Tigers to take control of a division that was awarded to them in Spring Training – waiting and waiting and waiting. It has been a season of false dawns for the Tigers, a ballclub that came within two victories of reaching the World Series last October.

The strength of the team is in their offense. There's been a breakout season from Austin Jackson, a fully functioning one-two punch of Prince Fielder and Miguel Cabrera and now a third musketeer in Brennan Boesch, which for one Detroit writer is a group conjuring up memories of Al Kaline, Norm Cash and Willie Horton. Still, despite the success of this weekend, albeit a sweep against faltering Cleveland, overall, Detroit's offense has only mustered up the seventh-most runs in the American League. The pitching staff didn't have the billing of Detroit's bats, but their performance has also been middle of the road, with the bullpen being slightly more reliable than the starters.

Luckily for these Tigers, the American League Central is a division that won't make you pay for such sputtering. Detroit are just 1.5 games behind the surprising first-place Chicago White Sox and have won five straight in reaching their high-water mark for the season, nine games over .500.

Tigers fans are hoping that their dramatic victory on Sunday is the springboard for the remainder of the 2012 season. Down two runs in the 10th inning with two outs and nobody on, Tribe closer Chris Perez issued a pair of walks to Alex Avila and Andy Dirks. Jackson drove home a run with a double, then Omar Infante's single tied it at eight. Cabrera came up and capped the improbable comeback with a two-run blast that sent spiraling Cleveland to their ninth straight defeat.

Before Tigers fans pop the cork on the champagne, we've seen this sort of surge before. Between 4 July and 22 July Detroit enjoyed a 13-2 run that included a sweep of the White Sox and a brief ascension into first place. Bad habits returned as they then dropped four of their next six games to slide back into second before rebounding against Cleveland. They host the Yankees for four games to start the week before flying to Texas for a weekend series.

Ray of light

There's good news on the horizon for fans of the Tampa Bay Rays. Out of the lineup since the end of April, Evan Longoria is on his way back to the big club, a move that will boost a sagging offense getting set for the 2012 stretch run. The 2012 Rays were always going to be about young pitching and just enough offense. With Longoria out of the lineup for over three months, Tampa have only mustered up enough runs to be ranked 12 of 14 teams, down from their 2011 run ranking of eighth. Longoria hit for a .994 OPS in 23 games this season before a hamstring injury forced the young slugger on the shelf. With Longoria on the field the Rays are 15-8 and with the third baseman on the DL they are 41-44.

Rays fans can thank their pitching staff for staying in the race. Tampa's young arms have the best ERA in the American League, and are more or less responsible for keeping the team afloat. Having Longoria, who will be limited to DH starting Tuesday, back in the lineup should, theoretically, provide enough offense to propel the them into the playoffs. The Tampa Bay Times tells us that the Rays have scored three or fewer runs in 11 of their 14 games, totals Longoria should be able impact once he gets up to speed.

On Sunday, manager Joe Maddon told the Tampa Bay Times:

"It definitely does something different to your lineup regarding who hits where, that kind of stuff. No question it would have some kind of positive impact. A hitter of his magnitude in your lineup always does. But my expectations aren't that he's just going to come in and just start railing on the baseball... I believe he's going to have to work his way through it and get back up to speed with major-league baseball players playing in August."

Even with Longoria, the website coolstandings.com doesn't think Tampa Bay are playoff material, giving the Rays just a 19.7% chance of taking a wild-card spot as of Monday. The saber-metric website gives the Tigers a 26.5% chance, the Angels a 36.1% chance, the A's a 35.6% chance and the Red Sox just a 14.6% chance.

No Reyes of light

Jose Reyes has turned it on. Unfortunately for Miami and their fans, it comes after the Marlins have fallen out of the race. Reyes has put together a garbage-time hitting streak of 24 games, during which he is hitting at a clip approaching .400.

Yes, it has been an impressive run for the shortstop who left New York to sign a seven-year, $106m contract with Miami, a team that also signed a host of other pricey free agents this offseason, including Mark Buehrle and Heath Bell. No, overall it has not worked out at all for manager Ozzie Guillen, who was also supposed to be a big addition to the team, and his club now find themselves fighting to stay out of the cellar with another team that unexpectedly floundered, the Philadelphia Phillies. At least the Phills had something of an excuse, losing Chase Utley and Ryan Howard for most of the season. Miami has none – the talent was there, but the wins were not.

At the center of the storm surrounding the Marlins disappointing season was Hanley Ramirez, now with LA, but Reyes, meant to be the catalyst of this team, must also take a large hit for its failure. Many Mets fans were reluctant to see one of their franchise cornerstones leave town over the winter, myself included. However, it's time to start wondering whether Reyes is just one of those players who struggles to win in big spots. The Mets collapsed down the stretch for many reasons in 2007 and 2008 and one of them was Reyes, who hit .205 and then .243 in those Septembers to forget. In the spring of 2009 I can remember watching Holland upset the Dominican Republic, not once but twice, and seeing Reyes looking confounded on the bench. I recall thinking: "Oh man, it's Reyes, he's a losing ballplayer!" Reyes battled injuries the next few seasons, bad ones for New York, before winning the batting title a year ago on another bad Mets team. This season, front and center, on a team with the talent to win, Reyes failed to lead his club to victories. Again, the Marlins have more issues than Reyes, but the contract he signed was for more than just hits and steals – it was to take responsibility for a team with expectations.

Now, with the Marlins in the NL East basement and the team in sell-mode, Reyes has finally turned it on – much, much too late.

The Voice

There may be no baseball activity more inviting than listening in to a Dodgers game and hearing "The Voice", regardless of whether or not you are a fan of the team. Of all the debates involving the game of baseball, the question of who is the best broadcaster in the booth is answered quickly and concisely by nearly all fans. It is Vin Scully, who has been calling Dodgers games, mostly on his own, going back to 1950 when the team was located in Brooklyn.

Scully's voice calms instantly and personally, knowing that he may not be long for the microphone, I'm taking in every word as often as possible. I am not alone of course, and proof of his reach was showcased on Saturday when Scully decided he would try provide a boost to Dodgers catcher AJ Ellis by employing the powers of Twitter. Scully, inspired by Ellis' two home runs in LA's 6-1 victory over the Cubs, thought it would be "cool" to get #AJEllis trending on the social network, and asked fans to chip in. Scully always impresses, but embracing social networking tools that were nowhere to be found 62 years ago when the Bronx born Scully moved into the booth at Brooklyn's Ebbets Field, represents an amusing high-water mark for the iconic broadcaster. At Scully's request #AJEllis was trending on Twitter in the United States, and the Dodgers catcher picked up about 800 followers on the night. That counts as major progress for the 84-year-old Scully, who days earlier was referring to tweets as "a twitter" or "twit".
